anxiety_references.title: World Health Organization on Anxiety Disorders
anxiety_references.description: World Health Organization on Anxiety Disorders, symptoms, diagnosis, treatments, prevention, and more.

anxiety_references.title: Anxiety signs and symptoms - Find support
anxiety_references.description: We all feel anxious sometimes, it’s a normal part of life. If your anxious feelings start to impact your quality of life and day-to-day functioning, it can be a sign of an anxiety condition. On this page we explain the signs and symptoms of anxiety conditions to look out for. - Beyond Blue

anxiety_references.title: Anxiety Prevention and Stories - Playlist
anxiety_references.description: A playlist full of people's stories, advices, and tips on how to prevent the spread of anxiety.

anxiety_references.title: Understanding anxiety disorders
anxiety_references.description: Anxiety disorders are serious mental illnesses that cause significant worry or fear that doesn't go away and may even get worse over time. We all feel anxious at times, but with an anxiety disorder, the anxiety tends to be fairly constant and has a very negative and intrusive impact on quality of life.

anxiety_references.title: Anxiety - Get medical attention (France)
anxiety_references.description: Doctolib distribue en France, en Italie, en Allemagne et aux Pays Bas un service de prise de rendez-vous en ligne, destiné aux patients. Le site web est principalement dédié aux services des professionnels de santé, exerçant dans un cadre réglementé (dotés d'un numéro RPPS ou inscrits à l'annuaire Adeli) une médecine conventionnelle ou non.

adhd_references.title: DSM-5 Diagnostic Criteria for ADHD
adhd_references.description: An overview of the DSM-5 classification for ADHD by the Association of American Foundation of Psychologists.

adhd_references.title: DSM-IV to DSM-5 Attention-Deficit/Hyperactivity Disorder Comparison
adhd_references.description: A comparison of the DSM-IV and DSM-5 classification for Attention-Deficit/Hyperactivity Disorder. This table can be useful to compare your symptoms with the one from the DSM-5 classification.

adhd_references.title: Topical Review: ADHD and Health-Risk Behaviors: Toward Prevention and Health Promotion
adhd_references.description: Across the lifespan, attention deficit/hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) is associated with increased health risk behaviors including substance abuse, binge eating and obesity, and unsafe sexual behavior. These risks are directly linked to the neurocognitive deficits associated with ADHD, and are also mediated by the cascade of psychosocial impairments and stressors caused by ADHD across development.

adhd_references.title: NACFC 2023 | S22: Let’s Focus on ADHD and Executive Functioning
adhd_references.description: The Cystic Fibrosis Foundation on the 2023 North American Cystic Fibrosis Conference

adhd_references.title: How ADHD Affects Adults | ADHD - Not Just for Kids (Full Documentary)
adhd_references.description: 'ADHD - Not Just for Kids' debunks some of the myths surrounding this invisible, cognitive disability as more and more adults are recognised as having ADHD or ADD. While following the personal journeys made by adults that was diagnosed with the disorder late in life, the documentary also challenges some of the most persistent myths surrounding ADHD, through interviews with some of the leading experts in the area and a look at the most recent research into the field.

adhd_references.title: Risks Associated With Undiagnosed ADHD and/or Autism: A Mixed-Method Systematic Review
adhd_references.description: The findings suggest that undiagnosed ASD/ADHD is linked to many risks and negative outcomes affecting individuals, their families, and the wider society. The restricted number of studies on ASD are a limitation to the generalization of these findings Implications for research and practice are discussed, highlighting the importance of screening and acknowledging the possibility of ASD/ADHD in many settings such as psychiatric and forensic.

adhd_references.title: ADHD - Get medical attention (France)
adhd_references.description: Trouvez un rendez-vous sur cette plateforme en ligne avec un expert du TDAH, pour diagnostiquer et soigner votre trouble.

adhd_references.title: The ADHD mini coach
adhd_references.description: ADHD presents in three main types: Inattentive, Hyperactive-Impulsive, and Combined. Each type affects individuals differently, influencing their attention, impulsivity, and activity levels. Recognizing the specific type of ADHD is crucial for effective treatment and management, tailoring strategies to meet individual needs. This differentiation helps understand the diverse symptoms and challenges, paving the way for targeted support and interventions.

adhd_references.title: ADHD - Get medical attention
adhd_references.description: Doctolib distribue en France, en Italie, en Allemagne et aux Pays Bas un service de prise de rendez-vous en ligne, destiné aux patients. Le site web est principalement dédié aux services des professionnels de santé, exerçant dans un cadre réglementé (dotés d'un numéro RPPS ou inscrits à l'annuaire Adeli) une médecine conventionnelle ou non.

autism_references.title: The history of autism
autism_references.description: It has been more than 50 years since Leo Kanner first described his classic autistic syndrome. Since then, the results of research and clinical work have helped us learn more about autism. More and more people are being diagnosed as autistic, although we still have a long way to go in creating a world that works for autistic people..

autism_references.title: Leo Kanner's biography
autism_references.description: Leo Kanner (/ˈkænər/; born Chaskel Leib Kanner; June 13, 1894 – April 3, 1981) was an Austrian-American psychiatrist, physician, and social activist best known for his work related to infantile autism.

autism_references.title: Validation of Proposed DSM-5 criteria for autism
autism_references.description: To explore the relative classification accuracy of DSM-IV-TR and DSM-5, autism symptoms from the SCQ and SRS were mapped onto DSM-IV-TR and proposed DSM-5.

autism_references.title: DSM-5 Diagnostic Criteria
autism_references.description: To explore the relative classification accuracy of DSM-IV-TR and DSM-5, autism symptoms from the SCQ and SRS were mapped onto DSM-IV-TR and proposed DSM-5.

autism_references.title: Comparison of the Diagnostic Criteria for Autism Spectrum Disorder Across DSM-5, DSM-IV-TR, and the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act (IDEA) Definition of Autism
autism_references.description: There's a huge difference in the diagnostic criterias of Autism between the DSM-5 and the DSM-IV ; this paper is a comparison table.

autism_references.title: Autism in simple terms
autism_references.description: In this post, let me address a common question among parents – What is autism in simple terms? When I try to explain to them that their child may be suspected of having autistic disorder, they are often confused on what Autism Spectrum Disorder actually is.

autism_references.title: Autism experience stories and history - Playlist
autism_references.description: A thoughtfully curated playlist dedicated to raising autism awareness, featuring a diverse collection of powerful personal testimonials and essential prevention tips. These videos aim to educate, inspire, and promote a deeper understanding and support for individuals on the autism spectrum

autism_references.title: Understanding The Impact of Undiagnosed Autism in Adults
autism_references.description: While there is a big focus on diagnosing and treating children with ASD, there are many individuals who go undiagnosed with autism until later in life. Astonishingly, in July 2022, around 125,000 people with a ‘suspected autism’ referral were waiting for a diagnosis – and 84% waited for more than 13 weeks to even get their first appointment. This delay can often lead to significant developmental challenges, which have a tremendous impact on a person’s health, social and professional life.

Bipolar disorder_references.title: DSM-IV to DSM-5 Bipolar I Disorder Comparison
Bipolar disorder_references.description: A comparison of the DSM-IV and DSM-5 classification for Bipolar disorder. This table can be useful to compare your symptoms with the one from the DSM-5 classification.

Bipolar disorder_references.title: What is Bipolar disorder?
Bipolar disorder_references.description: Bipolar disorder (formerly called manic-depressive illness or manic depression) is a mental illness that causes unusual shifts in a person’s mood, energy, activity levels, and concentration. These shifts can make it difficult to carry out day-to-day tasks.

Bipolar disorder_references.title: Myths and Facts of Bipolar disorder
Bipolar disorder_references.description: While the media is doing a better job today of depicting Bipolar disorder, such as in shows like “Euphoria,” “Homeland” and “Modern Love,” there are still many misconceptions when it comes to understanding this mood disorder.

Bipolar disorder_references.title: What is Bipolar disorder?
Bipolar disorder_references.description: Bipolar disorder is a mood disorder featuring manic, hypomanic, and/or depressive symptoms that are experienced in distinct episodes. We review the 3 types of Bipolar disorders, bipolar I, bipolar II, and cyclothymic disorder. Learn more about the symptoms and treatment options for Bipolar disorder.

Bipolar disorder_references.title: Shematic reprensentation of mood patterns in Bipolar disorder
Bipolar disorder_references.description: An illustration of manic, hypomanic, and depressive mood episodes in Bipolar disorder.

Bipolar disorder_references.title: Being bipolar (Psychology documentary)
Bipolar disorder_references.description: One minute you’re up and the next you’re down. But what if those ups were manias, generating feelings of omnipotence and invincibility? And what if those downs were depressions so stark, that you were left feeling immobile and even suicidal?

Bipolar disorder_references.title: Living with Bipolar disorder
Bipolar disorder_references.description: Explore the realities of living with Bipolar disorder.

Bipolar disorder_references.title: Treatment of Bipolar disorder
Bipolar disorder_references.description: A study on the treatment of Bipolar disorder.

bpd_references.title: DSM-5 Borderline Personality Disorder Criteria
bpd_references.description: DSM-5 Borderline Personality Disorder criteria. This article can be useful to compare your symptoms with the one from the DSM-5 classification.

bpd_references.title: What is Borderline Personality Disorder?
bpd_references.description: Borderline personality disorder (BPD) is a serious mental illness characterized by pervasive instability in moods, interpersonal relationships, self-image, and behavior. This instability often disrupts family and work life, long-term planning, and the individual's sense of self-identity.

bpd_references.title: Borderline Personality Disorder - Symptoms and Causes
bpd_references.description: Borderline personality disorder (BPD) is a mental health disorder that generates significant emotional instability. This can lead to a variety of other stressful mental and behavioral problems. With borderline personality disorder, you may have a severely distorted self-image and feel worthless and fundamentally flawed. Anger, impulsiveness and frequent mood swings may push others away, even though you desire loving relationships.

bpd_references.title: What is Borderline Personality Disorder?
bpd_references.description: Borderline Personality Disorder (BPD) is a mental health disorder that generates significant emotional instability. This can lead to a variety of other stressful mental and behavioral problems. With borderline personality disorder, you may have a severely distorted self-image and feel worthless and fundamentally flawed. Anger, impulsiveness and frequent mood swings may push others away, even though you desire loving relationships.

bpd_references.title: Psychiatrist Explains BPD (Borderline Personality Disorder) - Psychology 101
bpd_references.description: This video provides an in-depth understanding of Borderline Personality Disorder (BPD) for therapists. It explores the symptoms, causes, and treatment options for BPD. The video also offers insights into the emotional instability, distorted self-image, and interpersonal difficulties experienced by individuals with BPD. Therapists can gain valuable knowledge and strategies to effectively support and treat clients with BPD.

bpd_references.title: The Father of BPD Explains BPD (Borderline Personality Disorder) | JOHN GUNDERSON
bpd_references.description: John Gunderson, a major force in the BPD world and the person who originally defined the diagnosis, discusses Borderline Personality Disorder from the viewpoint of a researcher and clinician.

bpd_references.title: Borderline Personality Disorder - Symptoms and Causes
bpd_references.description: The term ‘borderline personality’ was proposed in the United States by Adolph Stern in 1938 (most other personality disorders were first described in Europe). Stern described a group of patients who ‘fit frankly neither into the psychotic nor into the psychoneurotic group’ and introduced the term ‘borderline’ to describe what he observed because it ‘bordered’ on other conditions.

bpd_references.title: Borderline Personality Disorder history
bpd_references.description: Come and learn about the history of BPD

bpd_references.title: Borderline Personality Disorder - Myths and Facts
bpd_references.description: Borderline personality disorder (BPD) is a serious mental illness characterized by pervasive instability in moods, interpersonal relationships, self-image, and behavior. This instability often disrupts family and work life, long-term planning, and the individual's sense of self-identity.

depression_references.title: Major Depressive Disorder - Symptoms and Causes
depression_references.description: Major depressive disorder is a mood disorder that affects how you feel, think, and behave. It causes feelings of sadness or a loss of interest in activities once enjoyed. It can lead to a variety of emotional and physical problems and can decrease a person’s ability to function at work and at home.

eds_and_body_dysmorphic_disorders_refere.description: Anorexia nervosa is a serious eating disorder that affects people of all ages. It is characterized by an intense fear of gaining weight and a distorted body image. People with anorexia nervosa have a low body weight and may restrict their food intake to dangerous levels.

ocd_references.title: What is ocd?
ocd_references.description: ocd (OCD) is a mental health disorder that affects people of all ages and walks of life, and occurs when a person gets caught in a cycle of obsessions and compulsions. Obsessions are unwanted, intrusive thoughts, images, or urges that trigger intensely distressing feelings. Compulsions are behaviors an individual engages in to attempt to get rid of the obsessions and/or decrease his or her distress.

ocd_references.title: ocd - Symptoms and Causes
ocd_references.description: ocd (OCD) is a mental health disorder that affects people of all ages and walks of life, and occurs when a person gets caught in a cycle of obsessions and compulsions. Obsessions are unwanted, intrusive thoughts, images, or urges that trigger intensely distressing feelings. Compulsions are behaviors an individual engages in to attempt to get rid of the obsessions and/or decrease his or her distress.

pmdd_references.title: What is pmdd?
pmdd_references.description: pmdd (PMDD) is a severe, sometimes disabling extension of premenstrual syndrome (PMS). Although regular PMS and PMDD both have physical and emotional symptoms, PMDD causes extreme mood shifts that can disrupt your work and damage your relationships.

ptsd_references.title: What is ptsd?
ptsd_references.description: ptsd (PTSD) is a mental health condition that's triggered by a terrifying event — either experiencing it or witnessing it. Symptoms may include flashbacks, nightmares, and severe anxiety, as well as uncontrollable thoughts about the event.

ptsd_references.title: Returning From the Iraq War With PTSD - The Soldier’s Heart (full documentary) | FRONTLINE
ptsd_references.description: This documentary follows the stories of soldiers returning from the Iraq War with ptsd (PTSD). It explores the challenges they face and the impact of PTSD on their lives.

schizophrenia_and_psychotic_diseases_ref.title: What is Schizophrenia?
schizophrenia_and_psychotic_diseases_ref.description: Schizophrenia is a serious mental disorder in which people interpret reality abnormally. Schizophrenia may result in some combination of hallucinations, delusions, and extremely disordered thinking and behavior that impairs daily functioning, and can be disabling.
